Title: Makassar city government's urban refugee policy: Filling in the gap?
Source title: IOP Conference Series: Earth and Environmental Science
Affiliations: Faculty Member of International Relations Department, Faculty of Humanities, Universitas Bina Nusantara, Jakarta, Indonesia; Deputy Head of International Relations Department, Faculty of Humanities, Universitas Bina Nusantara, Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Gabiella, D., Faculty Member of International Relations Department, Faculty of Humanities, Universitas Bina Nusantara, Jakarta, Indonesia; Putri, R.A.A.K., Deputy Head of International Relations Department, Faculty of Humanities, Universitas Bina Nusantara, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: Indonesia is home to 13,829 refugees and asylum seekers by the end of January 2017. In general, the number could be dichotomized into two categories: camp-based refugees and urban refugees. There are approximately 70.83% of urban refugees living in several cities across the country. The existence of refugees in urban environments has been considered as either bringing promise or peril to urban development. Makassar is one among the most populated cities by refugees in Indonesia. In the middle of the inadequacy of legal framework at the national level, the Makassar City Government initiated a policy to address the issues of refugees staying in the city specifically. In 2005, the Mayor of Makassar signed a Memorandum of Understanding with International Organization for Migration (IOM) to accommodate the needs for funding allocated from Regional Budget that could not be dispensed due to the absence of legal basis. The city also constituted a Joint Committee Monitoring (JCM), which comprises of various government agencies, to support the Immigration Office in monitoring the refugees. These initiatives allow refugees to access basic services that are not made available to them in other cities. Against this backdrop, this paper mainly discusses the initiatives and refugee policy of Makassar City Government, which had emulated the national government's policy to refugee management before the recently signed Presidential Decree No. 25 / 2016. It argues that the proactive and relatively integrative approach of the City Government alongside the social inclusion by the local community have contributed positively to the livelihoods of urban refugees in Makassar. © Published under licence by IOP Publishing Ltd.
Author Keywords: city government; Makassar; migration; refugee management; urban refugees
Index Keywords: Budget control; Urban growth; city government; Government agencies; International organizations; Makassar; Memorandum of understanding; migration; National governments; urban refugees; Public policy

Authors: Putri R.A.A.K., Moniaga J.V., Wijaya Y.
Title: A design model for digital game-based learning in the study of international relations: Developing an innovative learning method for a defense strategy course at Bina Nusantara University
Source title: 2016 1st International Conference on Game, Game Art, and Gamification, ICGGAG 2016
Affiliations: International Relations, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; School of Computer Science, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Putri, R.A.A.K., International Relations, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Moniaga, J.V., School of Computer Science, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Wijaya, Y., School of Computer Science, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: Digital Game-Based Learning (DGBL) has been tested and proved to be a viable solution for many educational challenges. This research aims to study several frameworks used to develop games for educational purposes and formulate a framework for the development of game-based learning, specifically for Strategic Studies in International Relations Department, Bina Nusantara University. Literature reviews of previously completed research studied existing frameworks and models, including the Mechanics, Dynamics, Aesthetics (MDA) Framework and the Analysis, Design, Development, Implementation, Evaluation (ADDIE) Model, as well as the First Principles of Learning for designing the content of the game. The result shows the implementation of these frameworks in the design process of the game, as well as the early development of the game presented as a prototype. © 2016 IEEE.
Author Keywords: digital game-based learning; game-based learning; international relations; strategic studies; video games)
Index Keywords: Bins; Computer games; Curricula; Design; Education; Human computer interaction; Digital game-based learning; Game-based Learning; International relations; Strategic study; Video game; E-learning
